Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.

Name: Miss Eleanor J. Webb
Address: Sandwith, Saskatchewan
Birthplace: Oldham, England

1. INDUSTRY (HOUSEKEEPING)
What year did you start housekeeping in eastern Canada? 1917
Where did you set up housekeeping? Sandwith, Saskatchewan
Where had you been living before that? Windsor, Ontario
For how many people did you prepare meals?
How far was it to your nearest store?
How often could a visit be made to the store?
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
What brand of white flour did you use in the early years?
In what quantities did you buy it? 50 lb., and 100 lb. at times
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? 6 dollars
How much did you use graham flour?
Whole wheat flour?
Was flour milled locally? Yes, how far away? 37 miles, that year? 1915
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? Around 70 cents
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal?
Whole wheat?
Farina?
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Sometimes
How did you grind it? With grain chaffers
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 20 pounds.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? $1.50.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Royal's golden syrup.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 48 ounces.

At what price? around $1.00.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? milk cows.

Butter? Yes, how much? 15 cents.

What was the price of butter? 15 cents.

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes, how many? 20 dozen.

Did you make butter? Yes, cheese?

What kind of cheese? Cream cheese & ewe cheese.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Beef & pork.

How did you get fresh meat? 

How often did you get fresh meat? In twenty times.

How did you preserve meat? Salted.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? No.

If so what year was it organized?

Did you use game? Yes, what kinds? Pheasant, chicken, and ducks.

For how long? Just once in a while.

What part did fish play in the family diet? None.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned?

Kinds? Didn't get much often.
3. **Selling and Buying**

In what quantity did you buy? (e.g., 26 pounds)

What was the price per pound? (e.g., $1.50 per pound)

Did you pay cash or credit? (e.g., cash)

Did you use any coupons? (e.g., yes)

4. **Baking**

How did you make the dough? (e.g., by hand)

What kind of flour did you use? (e.g., all-purpose)

Did you add any ingredients? (e.g., sugar, salt)

Did you use any special techniques? (e.g., kneading)

5. **Meat and Fish**

What was your main source of meat? (e.g., beef)

How did you cook it? (e.g., roasted)

How often did you eat meat? (e.g., twice a week)

Was there a meat plant in your neighborhood? (e.g., yes)

If so, what type was it? (e.g., butcher shop)

Did you use any spices? (e.g., yes)

For how long? (e.g., 1-2 weeks)

Did you store it in the refrigerator? (e.g., yes)

Was the fish fresh, canned, or frozen? (e.g., fresh)

How was it prepared? (e.g., baked)
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Blue Willow. At what price? 40 cents.

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Ground.

Price? ________________ That other beverages were used? __________________

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? 20 cents.

Could you get potatoes at the store? No.

If not, where from? From our own.

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of: 1918.

Potatoes __________ Cabbage __________ Carrots __________ Onions __________

Turnips __________ Beets __________

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 5-10 pounds at a time.

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? Bulk.

What weight? 30 lbs. How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? __________

What was the price of prunes? 25 cents.

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currents or others)? All.

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? No.

Peas? Yes. Corn? No. Beans? No. Saskatoons? No.

Other foods? __________

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1918.

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1918.

What year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1923 & 24.

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Canning.

To what extent? Not a great lot.

Did you make your own vinegar? No.
6. Vegetables and Fruits

What kind of tea did you buy? (Lochaber)

At what price? (Lochaber)

What kind of coffee did you buy? (Lochaber or normal)

Price?

That other beverages were used?

7. Vegetables and Fruits

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you got up housekeeping?

Could you get potatoes at the store?

If not, where from?

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of?

Potatoes

Carrots

Onions

In what quantities did you buy these navy beans?

What was the price of prunes?

That other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apricots, peaches, raisins, currants, or others)?

8. Preserving

In the early years did you preserve any foods by canning?

That year did you first preserve fruit by canning?

That year did you first preserve fruit by freezing?

That year did you first preserve meat by canning?

Do you still preserve foods by canning or freezing?

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, slough, dugout) ........................................... Well ........................................................

How far was this water from your home? ........................................... In the yard ........................................................

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) ........................................... Pail ........................................................

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.
12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, cistern, dugout)

If so, for how long have you had it?

Was it brought to the house by (pail, barrel, tank) first started homesteading, giving date please.

First started homesteading, giving date please.
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or wood ashes? Yes

If you made your own, did you use lye? No

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Soap

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Wood

Where did you get your fuel? Out of town home

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

No change

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) No

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) Stove

By whom was your first cook stove made? My mom made it at home

What year was it purchased? 1920

Price? $20

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade)

Enamel ware and some tin ware

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other)

Reliance on earthenware

When did you first see enamel ware? When I started housekeeping

Aluminum? When started housekeeping

1918
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Mostly paper bags.

17. Give a typical daily menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast: porridge, toast, eggs
Dinner: meat & potatoes, pudding for dessert
Supper: fish & meat, syrup

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada? .................. Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details. No
15. **SHIPPING AND CONTAINERS**
   Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).
   
   *Mostly paper bags*

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. Also the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.
   
   *Breakfast: porridge, toast, eggs*
   
   *Dinner: meat & potatoes, pudding for dessert*
   
   *Supper: meat & meat syrup*

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Eastern Canada? .................. Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

We used cells of storing our vegetables.
21. When all you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of home grown and home prepared foods (Give us every detail and dates as possible). For always prepared every food.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of border gardening and any other foods in other parts of the world. In Southern Canada, tomatoes, beans not considered above, quality, methods of cultivation, etc.

The word tally of vegetables
